column1: Norrköping (; Swedish: [ˈnɔ̂rːˌɕøːpɪŋ] (listen)) is a city in the province of Östergötland in eastern Sweden and the seat of Norrköping Municipality
column2: Östergötland County
column3: about 160 km southwest of the national capital Stockholm
column4: 40 km east of county seat Linköping and 60 km west of the Södermanland capital of Nyköping. The city has a population of 95
column6: out of a municipal total of 130
column8: making it Sweden's tenth largest city and eighth largest municipality.

column1: The city is situated by the mouth of the river Motala ström
column2: at Bråviken
column3: an inlet of the Baltic Sea. Water power from the Motala ström and the good harbour were factors that facilitated the rapid growth of this once industrial city
column4: known for its textile industry. It has several nicknames such as: "Sweden's Manchester"
column5: "Peking" and "Surbullestan" (Surbulle [sour bun] was a local nickname for the textile workers
column6: and stan is short for Staden
column7: which means The City or The Town in Swedish).

column1: The city has medieval foundations by settlers around the Motala stream estuary
column2: who used the falls and rapids to power their mills. The stream was also full of fish such as salmon. Exact dates are uncertain
column3: but there are mentions of a church in the 12th century. It was dedicated to Saint Olaf

column1: The first trace of the city's name is from 1283
column2: when Sophia of Denmark donated her rights of salmon fishing to the Skänninge monastery. The town is estimated to have received city status in the early 14th century
column3: although no written documents exist prior to a document from 1384. This document
column4: signed by Albrekt of Sweden is stored in the city archive today. Köping means there was a market there
column5: while Nörr or Norr means "north". There is a smaller town nearby named Söderköping

column1: The city was the location of several battles in the ensuing centuries. As a consequence
column2: nothing of the medieval Norrköping remains today. During the Northern Seven Years' War (1563–1570)
column3: the entire southern part of Norrköping was burnt. It was rebuilt by John III of Sweden
column4: who designed the current street pattern.

column2: a weapon industry was established by supervision of Gustavus Adolphus. The harbour also attracted ships due to its proximity to the industries of Finspång. In addition to the weapon industry
column3: a large scale industry of textile was also initiated. An important benefactor was the industrial man Louis De Geer (1587–1652). At De Geer's death
column5: 000 inhabitants and was Sweden's second largest city.

column2: and again in 1719 during the Russian Pillage of 1719-21 when the Russians burnt it to the ground. Stones from the Johannisborg castle were used to build new houses
column3: and today only a few stones remain.

column1: During the 18th century it was rebuilt and several industries soon got a stronghold: In the 1740s
column2: Norrköping boasted three sugar refineries; in the 1750s the large scale influential snus industry was established. From this time stems the city churches of Saint Olof and Saint Hedvig
column3: and several other old houses. In 1762
column4: the first theater in Sweden outside of Stockholm was established in the city

column1: Norrköping's importance again flourished. In 1769 the Swedish Riksdag assembled there. In 1800 King Gustav IV of Sweden was crowned in the Church of Saint Olof.
In the later 18th and early 19th Centuries
column2: Norrköping was one of the three Swedish cities where Jews were allowed to live (see History of the Jews in Sweden).

column1: The city again suffered fires in 1822 and 1826. Thereafter wooden houses were banned. In 1841 a ship industry was initiated as a branch of Motala Verkstad in Motala. In 1850 the industry had over 600 employees making it Sweden's largest ship industry at the time. During the remaining 19th century
column2: the industries kept expanding. The area by the Motala Stream was developed further with the construction of a cotton refinery
column3: and a paper mill was constructed in 1854
column5: and is still today exporting to customers around the world.

column2: including textile manufacturers
column3: also expanded into the 20th century. In 1950 a total of 54 factories had 6
column6: 18 of them had been closed due to competition from countries abroad with lower wages
column7: such as Italy and Japan. In 1970 only 10 factories and 1
column12: and another 900 people were let go. To counter the effects
column13: several governmental authorities were relocated to Norrköping from Stockholm. See also Braviken Paper Mill.

column2: Norrköping is now seeing a revival
column3: as a center of culture and education. The Norrköping symbol represents the "new" Norrköping.

column1: The Motala ström river flows through the city has a parade annexed. In connection to the latter is the industrial landscape where the old textile industries once were situated.In the summer
column2: there is a cactus plantation in Carl Johans Park. 25
column3: 000 cacti planted there every summer.Kolmårdens Djurpark is a zoo located 30 km (19 mi) north of Norrköping. In connection to the large outdoor zoo
column7: crocodiles and sharks can be seen.The archipelagos 50 km (31 mi) away from Norrköping are called St Anna and Gryt.A campus of Linköping University
column11: a high-tech industry park called Norrköping Science Park
column12: and Petroglyphs from the Nordic Bronze Age.

column1: Norrköping had a humid continental climate for the reference period of 1961–1990
column2: but it was borderline four-season oceanic during that period and has since more resembled the latter
column3: with somewhat warmer temperatures year-round. In spite of it being located near the Baltic Sea
column4: Norrköping has a relatively dry climate with precipitation levels averaging 508.2 millimetres (20.01 in) between 1961 and 1990. That would in turn be very low for a marine climate
column5: but some way above more arid climates. The humidity for most of the year combined with there being no pronounced dry season keeps the surroundings green in spite of the rain shadow effect. Winter precipitation is quite low
column6: but often falls as snow. On August 26
column8: Norrköping set a nationwide record for the hottest temperature in the latter parts of August with 32.7 °C (90.9 °F) during a sudden and brief burst of extreme heat.

column1: The Swedish Transport Agency has its headquarters in Norrköping. as well as the main office of the Swedish Meteorological and Hydrological Institute (SMHI)  When the Civil Aviation Administration existed
column2: its head office was in Norrköping. Norrköping is one of two Swedish cities (the other being Gothenburg) that retained its tram system after the 1967 conversion to right-hand drive

column1: It has air service at Norrköping Airport and rail service at Norrköping Central Station.

column2: Egges Theatre
column3: hosted the first Scandinavian performance of Shakespeare's Romeo and Juliet in 1776
column4: and the city has a long theatre and revue tradition. Current main theatres are Östgötateatern (Sweden's biggest regional theatre) from 1947 and Arbisteatern from 1865.
